none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from Harrington, July 22, 1890
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from Harrington, July 22, 1890
Box 2 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 2 Folder 3 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
[Header]

STATION STAFF.
F. A. GULLEY, M. Sc. Director.
G. W. CURTIS, M. S. A., Agriculturist.
H. H. HARRINGTON, M. Sc., Chemist.
T. L. BRUNK, B. Sc., Horticulturalist.
M. FRANCIS, D. V. M., Veterinarian.
W. WIPPRECHT, B. S. A., Asst. Chem.
D. ADRIANCE, Asst. Chemist.
J. W. CARSON, Asst. to Director.
J. M. CARSON, Asst. to Agriculturist.
C. K. FUQUA, B. Sc., Sugar Chemist.
HARLEM, FORT BEND CO.

TEXAS
Agricultural + Experiment + Station,
Agricultural and Mechanical College.
ADDRESS ALL COMMUNICATIONS TO EXPERIMENT STATION.

BOARD OF CONTROL.
BOARD OF DIRECTORS,
Agricultural and Mechanical College.
EXPERIMENT STATION COUNCIL,
L. L. McINNIS, Chairman of Faculty.
T. M. SCOTT, Agent of the Board.
F. A. GULLEY, Director of the Station.

College Station, Texas July 22d 1890

Dear Prof. -- I saw Whitlock and Francis. -- The
latter said he would be willing to sign it if
he thought it would do any good -- but expressed
doubt in that direction. -- As I left said he would
sign it if Whitlock would -- [illegible] Went to see
Whitlock. He said he would be glad to sign it
but had not known that you wanted to remain
and had endorsed Smith -- asking that he be
put in as associate for two years -- and to
now ask for your retention, would as he believ-
ed place him in a dual position before
the Board. -- So nothing was done -- Did not
get to see Maj Bringhurst as it was already late
and he had gone up to his room. --
After all, I presume the matter will be
settled either according to what the Board have
already determined or according to what Maj
Bringhurst may wish, if Curtis is not consulted
in the matter. -- But I was anxious to put
these men to the test and to also let the
Board know there was no animus in the
Faculty against you. --

**Here's how I'm approaching this transcription task:** I'm starting by understanding the scope of the request: I need to transcribe the text from a handwritten document, adhering to specific guidelines about accuracy, formatting (including HTML tags), and reading order. I'm focusing on providing *only* the transcribed text. I've analyzed the image to understand its structure. I can see the date is July 22nd, 1890, and the handwriting is cursive but generally legible, though there are some crossed-out words. The content revolves around getting signatures related to someone's continued employment. I need to note the layout: center header (TEXAS...), left sidebar (Station Staff), right sidebar (Board). My process involves a line-by-line transcription. I'm paying close attention to spelling, punctuation, and handwriting interpretation, keeping the original formatting as closely as possible, and preserving the intended meaning. I'll use the HTML tags as needed for layout (using `

The sidebars will be transcribed in the order they appear. The 'd' in "22d" is definitely superscripted, and I will use ` for that. I've noted a few instances of handwriting that I'll have to carefully transcribe. I will address any crossed-out sections. I'll stick to transcribing the text without adding comments. I've carefully examined the handwriting and interpreted it, and I'm ready to produce the final transcription as directed.

I thought you would be curious to know
how the matter came out, and would
have told you befor leaving, but no opportu -
nity was offered - Whitlock unhesitatingly said
he did not think the Board were doing you
right - and spoke very freely about the matter -
Hoping for the best

Faithfully yours.
[Signature] H

[Boxed annotation:]
Harrington
By Mrs L G B McGuire [?]
11/30/52 gBc
[Red pencil:] obs
